column1: What are the key stages in the major overhaul process for mechanical and electrical equipment?
column2: ['The major overhaul process for mechanical and electrical equipment is typically divided into three stages: pre-repair preparation, the repair process itself, and post-repair acceptance.', "Pre-repair preparation phase To ensure the repair work proceeds smoothly and accurately, maintenance personnel should carefully listen to operators' requirements for equipment repairs and thoroughly understand the issues affecting the equipment being servicedâ€”such as loss of precision, the extent of wear on major mechanical components, the accuracy of the transmission system, and any visible defects."]
column3: The major overhaul process for mechanical and electrical equipment consists of three distinct stages: pre-repair preparation, the actual repair process, and post-repair acceptance. During the pre-repair preparation phase, maintenance personnel must carefully listen to operator requirements and thoroughly understand equipment issues including precision loss, wear extent on major mechanical components, transmission system accuracy, and visible defects. This phase also involves reviewing technical documentation, equipment manuals, and previous maintenance records to understand the device's structural features, transmission system, and original precision standards. The preparation enables the team to propose comprehensive pre-inspection tasks, determine specific repair methods for critical components, prepare specialized tools and precision measuring instruments, and establish post-repair precision testing procedures with clear acceptance criteria for trial runs.

column1: What specific activities are involved in a major overhaul of electromechanical equipment?
column2: ['An overhaul involves completely or largely disassembling the equipment, repairing or replacing foundational components, refurbishing mechanical and electrical parts, recalibrating the electrical systems, and finally reassembling and fine-tuning the entire unit.', 'The major steps involved in the overhaul of mechanical and electrical equipment typically include: pre-disassembly unit inspection, component removal, component inspection, necessary component disassembly, parts cleaning and examination, component repair and assembly, final assembly, no-load trial operation, load testing, overall machine precision verification, and final acceptance.']
column3: A major overhaul of electromechanical equipment involves comprehensive activities including complete or substantial disassembly of the equipment, repair or replacement of foundational components, refurbishment of both mechanical and electrical parts, recalibration of electrical systems, and complete reassembly with fine-tuning. The specific major steps include: pre-disassembly unit inspection to assess the equipment's condition, systematic component removal, thorough inspection of all components, necessary disassembly of sub-components, comprehensive cleaning and examination of all parts, repair and reassembly of components, final assembly of the complete unit, no-load trial operation to test basic functionality, load testing to verify performance under operational conditions, precision verification of the entire machine to ensure it meets specified standards, and final acceptance procedures to confirm the overhaul meets all requirements. These activities must be carried out according to the overhaul work plan with effective job scheduling and quality control throughout the process.

column1: What is the first step in the maintenance process stage?
column2: ["Once the maintenance process begins, the first step is to disassemble the equipmentâ€”following a sequence and approach that reverses the original assembly order, adhering to the principle of 'top-down and outside-in.'"]
column3: The first step in the maintenance process stage is to disassemble the equipment. This disassembly follows a specific sequence and approach that reverses the original assembly order, adhering to the principle of 'top-down and outside-in.' This systematic method ensures that components are carefully released from their interlocking and fixed positions within the machine.

column1: How does the pre-repair technical condition of equipment affect the outcome of a major overhaul?
column2: ['The precision and performance achievable during equipment maintenance depend on factors such as the technical expertise available for repair work, the number of major overhauls the equipment has undergone, and its pre-repair technical condition.', 'if the equipment was in relatively good technical condition prior to the last overhaul, it will likely be easier to restore its quality closer to the original factory standards this time around. Conversely, if the previous overhaul left the equipment in suboptimal condition, it may create significant challenges for the next major repairâ€”and in some cases, the resulting quality might even fail to meet the original factory standards, making further repairs impractical altogether.']
column3: The pre-repair technical condition of the equipment significantly influences the outcome of a major overhaul. If the equipment was in relatively good technical condition before the overhaul, it is easier to restore its quality closer to the original factory standards. Conversely, if the equipment was left in suboptimal condition after a previous overhaul, it creates significant challenges for the next major repair. In such cases, the resulting quality may fail to meet the original factory standards, and further repairs could become impractical.

column1: What is involved in the post-repair acceptance phase?
column2: ['All equipment that has undergone repair, assembly, and adjustment must be subjected to comprehensive precision checks and testsâ€”such as geometric accuracy inspections, no-load running tests, load tests, and working precision evaluationsâ€”in accordance with the relevant prescribed accuracy standards or the precision criteria established prior to repair.', 'These measures ensure a thorough assessment of the repaired equipmentâ€™s quality, restored precision, and overall performance.', 'After equipment maintenance, record the modifications made to the original technical documentation and document any lessons learned during the repair process. Prepare a thorough post-repair summary and file it alongside the original documents for future reference during the next maintenance task.']
column3: The post-repair acceptance phase involves comprehensive precision checks and tests on all repaired, assembled, and adjusted equipment. These include geometric accuracy inspections, no-load running tests, load tests, and working precision evaluations, all conducted according to relevant prescribed accuracy standards or pre-repair precision criteria. This ensures a thorough assessment of the equipment's quality, restored precision, and overall performance. Additionally, modifications to the original technical documentation must be recorded, lessons learned during the repair process documented, and a detailed post-repair summary prepared and filed with the original documents for future maintenance reference.

column1: What are the key aspects of preparation for equipment maintenance?
column2: ['Preparation for equipment maintenance involves two key aspects: technical preparation and production readiness.', 'The technical preparation prior to maintenance is the responsibility of the lead technician, and its main tasks include pre-inspection planning and research, conducting the actual pre-inspection, and preparing comprehensive overhaul technical documentation.', 'Meanwhile, production readiness before the overhaul is managed by personnel responsible for spare parts, materials, and tools, as well as the production planners from the maintenance unit. Their primary responsibilities encompass ordering, manufacturing, inspecting, and storing critical materials, spare parts, and specialized tools, gauges, and testing equipmentâ€”along with developing the overall maintenance production schedule.']
column3: Preparation for equipment maintenance consists of two key aspects: technical preparation and production readiness. Technical preparation, managed by the lead technician, includes pre-inspection planning and research, conducting the pre-inspection, and preparing comprehensive overhaul technical documentation. Production readiness, handled by spare parts, materials, and tools personnel along with maintenance unit production planners, involves ordering, manufacturing, inspecting, and storing critical materials, spare parts, specialized tools, gauges, and testing equipment, as well as developing the overall maintenance production schedule.

column1: What should be checked during the inspection of the machine tool's operational condition?
column2: ["Check the machine tool's operational condition: Verify whether the control system responds sensitively and reliably during movement; ensure that all movements meet the specified values; and confirm that the motion is smooth, without vibrations, noise, or stick-slip phenomena."]
column3: During the inspection of the machine tool's operational condition, several aspects must be verified. First, the control system should be checked to ensure it responds sensitively and reliably during movement. Second, all movements must meet the specified values as required. Finally, the motion should be confirmed to be smooth, without any vibrations, noise, or stick-slip phenomena, indicating proper mechanical function and alignment.

column1: What are the key elements included in the equipment maintenance technical specification?
column2: ['The equipment maintenance technical specification should include the following content. â‘?The technical condition of the equipment before major overhaul. â‘?Key maintenance activities include detailing the disassembly, cleaning, and inspection of components to identify parts that require repair or replacement; briefly outlining the repair methods for basic and critical components; specifying mechanisms that must be thoroughly inspected and adjusted, as well as other areas requiring attention; and highlighting specific parts and aspects that can be improved during the overhaul process. â‘?Maintenance quality requirements: Specify the names and numbers of the general technical standards applicable to each quality inspection during major equipment overhauls, and attach the content of any specialized technical standards to the back of the task specification.']
column3: The equipment maintenance technical specification includes three main elements. First, it documents the technical condition of the equipment before the major overhaul, providing a baseline for assessment. Second, it outlines key maintenance activities, such as detailing the disassembly, cleaning, and inspection processes to identify parts needing repair or replacement; briefly describing repair methods for basic and critical components; specifying mechanisms that require thorough inspection and adjustment; and highlighting areas for potential improvement during the overhaul. column1: What is included in the preparation of spare parts and materials before equipment maintenance?

column3: The preparation of spare parts and materials involves the lead technical personnel providing the management team with detailed lists of replacement parts, material specifications, and lists of specialized tools, inspection equipment, and research fixtures, accompanied by relevant drawings. After inventory verification, the management team places orders or arranges manufacturing to ensure timely availability of these items for major equipment overhauls.

column1: How is the overhaul work plan developed and what does it include?
column2: ['The overhaul work plan is prepared by the planning personnel in the maintenance department, who are responsible for equipment management. Personnel, chief technicians, and maintenance foremen (team leaders) review it together.', 'The overhaul work plan includes: work procedures, the number of workers required for each phase and stage of the job, along with the corresponding duration in days; requirements for seamless coordination between individual work phases; and details on projects that need to be outsourced to external partners, including specific timeframes.', "A general overhaul work plan can be presented using a 'bar chart' format, supplemented by necessary explanatory text. column3: The general technical requirements for part processing quality in major machine tool repairs include three key aspects. column1: What are the requirements for the lubrication system to be considered completely intact?

column1: What specifications apply to oiling devices and their protective covers?

column1: What are the requirements for wire identification in machine tool control circuits?

column1: What are the steps for testing the main drive mechanism of a machine tool?

column3: The main drive mechanism test involves starting from the lowest speed and sequentially running through each gear stage, maintaining each speed for at least 2 minutes. The highest speed must be run continuously for no less than 30 minutes to ensure the spindle bearings reach a stable temperature. Additionally, for machine tools with change gears, belt-driven variable-speed systems, or stepless transmissions, gear-shifting operations at low, medium, and high speeds are required.

column1: What temperature checks are required after the spindle bearings reach stable temperature?

column1: What are the key components of machine tool maintenance testing?
column2: ['The key components of machine tool maintenance testing include no-load running tests, load tests, and working precision tests.', 'The machine tool load test evaluates whether the machineâ€™s main motion system can achieve the maximum torque and power allowed by the design, as well as checks if all machine components are functioning properly under these conditions, whether there are any positional changes between parts, and if such changes remain within the permissible limits.', 'The purpose of the machine tool working accuracy test is to determine whether the positional accuracy between the machineâ€™s various components during the machining process meets the precision requirements of the parts being manufactured.']
column3: Machine tool maintenance testing consists of three key components: no-load running tests, load tests, and working precision tests. The no-load running test verifies the correct functioning, reliability, and operational normality of each machine component while checking temperature rise and noise levels. The load test evaluates whether the main motion system can achieve the designed maximum torque and power, checks component functionality under load conditions, monitors positional changes between parts, and ensures vibrations, noise, and temperature rise remain within acceptable limits. The working accuracy test determines if the positional accuracy between machine components during machining meets part precision requirements, typically involving machining test pieces with specified tools and parameters according to established standards.

column1: What preparations are required before conducting a machine tool's no-load operation test?
column2: ['Before conducting the no-load operation test of the machine tool, ensure that all major overhaul tasks have been completed and that each repair has met the required quality standards.', 'Next, fill all oil reservoirs with lubricant and properly grease all lubrication points.', 'Only after completing all necessary preparations in accordance with the safety operating procedures can you proceed with the no-load tests as outlined by the precision inspection standards specific to the machine tool being used.']
column3: Before conducting a machine tool's no-load operation test, several critical preparations must be completed. First, all major overhaul tasks must be finished, with each repair meeting the required quality standards. Second, all oil reservoirs must be filled with appropriate lubricant, and all lubrication points must be properly greased to ensure adequate lubrication during operation. Finally, all necessary preparations must be completed in strict accordance with safety operating procedures. Only after these steps are fulfilled can the no-load tests proceed according to the precision inspection standards specific to that particular machine tool, ensuring safe and accurate testing conditions.

column1: What are the general principles and requirements for mechanical equipment disassembly?
column2: ['The primary purpose of dismantling machinery is to facilitate the inspection and repair of its components; in fact, the disassembly process typically accounts for about 20% of the total maintenance workload.', 'Therefore, to ensure high-quality repairs, itâ€™s essential to carefully plan ahead and anticipate potential challenges before starting to take apart the equipment.', 'This way, the dismantling can proceed methodicallyâ€”following a structured approach that adheres to the following rules and guidelines.']
column3: The general principles for mechanical equipment disassembly emphasize careful planning and methodical execution to support high-quality repairs. Disassembly primarily serves to enable inspection and repair of components, representing approximately 20% of total maintenance work. Key requirements include anticipating challenges beforehand and following a structured approach with specific rules and guidelines to ensure the process is efficient and maintains equipment integrity.

column1: What preparations are needed before disassembling mechanical equipment?
column2: ['Preparations Before Disassembly (1) Selection and Cleanup of the Disassembly Site. Before disassembly, choose an appropriate work areaâ€”avoid locations prone to windblown sand or dust.', 'The workspace should be kept free from frequent unauthorized access by unrelated personnel to prevent unnecessary disruptions or accidents.', 'Additionally, ensure that the ground in the work area remains clean, free from dirt, oil, or other contaminants.']
column3: Several critical preparations are required before disassembling mechanical equipment. First, select and prepare an appropriate disassembly site by choosing a location not prone to windblown sand or dust, keeping it free from unauthorized access to prevent disruptions, and ensuring the ground is clean without dirt, oil, or contaminants. All machinery must undergo external cleaning before entering the site to protect equipment precision. Protective measures include removing or safeguarding electrical devices against moisture during cleaning and applying protective maintenance to oxidation- and rust-prone parts. Additionally, drain lubricating oil while it is still hot to facilitate smoother disassembly. Finally, thoroughly understand the equipment's structure, performance, operating principles, component features, transmission system, design characteristics, part interrelationships, and functions to plan disassembly logically and select proper tools.

column1: What are the general principles for disassembling mechanical equipment?
column2: ['Based on the structural characteristics of the mechanical equipment, select a logical disassembly sequence. Typically, the process involves dismantling from the overall unit into subassemblies, then breaking down subassemblies into individual components, and finally separating components into their constituent partsâ€”or alternatively, proceeding from accessories to the main unit and from external elements inward.', 'When disassembling particularly complex components, itâ€™s essential to thoroughly study the assembly drawings and carefully analyze the componentâ€™s structure as well as the specific roles its parts play within the assembly.', 'During the maintenance and disassembly of mechanical equipment, adhere to the principle of avoiding unnecessary disassembly while ensuring that components requiring removal are indeed taken apart.']
column3: The general principles for disassembling mechanical equipment include selecting a logical disassembly sequence based on structural characteristics, typically proceeding from the overall unit to subassemblies, then to individual components, and finally to constituent partsâ€”or alternatively from accessories to the main unit and from external elements inward. For complex components, it's essential to study assembly drawings and analyze the component's structure and the roles of its parts, paying special attention to high-precision assembly components. The process should adhere to rational disassembly by avoiding unnecessary removal while ensuring required components are taken apart. Additionally, proper tool usage is critical: after understanding removal steps, select and apply appropriate disassembly tools, preferring specialized or matched equipment to prevent part damage or deformation, and avoiding random hammering or forceful techniques.

column1: What precautions should be taken during mechanical equipment disassembly?
column2: ['Ensure thorough verification or marking of disassembled parts. Mechanical equipment often contains numerous precisely matched components and parts, many of which have been specifically selected or balanced for weightâ€”meaning their assembly positions and orientations must not be altered under any circumstances.', 'Store parts by category. When storing disassembled parts, follow these principles: Parts belonging to the same type or component should be kept together whenever possible; store items according to their size and precision level; non-interchangeable parts must be stored separately in groups; delicate components that are sensitive to dirt or damage should be removed and stored individually; rubber parts should never be stored alongside oil-bearing components; and ensure that easily lost items are carefully accounted for.', 'Protect the machined surfaces of removed parts. During disassembly, never damage the machined surfaces of the components being taken apartâ€”doing so could complicate repair work and lead to issues such as air, oil, or water leaks, ultimately resulting in reduced performance of the mechanical equipment.']
column3: Key precautions during mechanical equipment disassembly include thorough verification and marking of parts, as many components are precisely matched, specifically selected, or weight-balanced, requiring their original assembly positions and orientations to be preserved. If original markings are unclear or missing, they must be re-marked accurately. Parts should be stored by category: keep same-type or same-component parts together; sort by size and precision; group non-interchangeable parts separately; individually store delicate, dirt-sensitive components; never store rubber parts with oil-bearing components; and carefully account for easily lost items. Additionally, protect machined surfaces from damage during disassembly to avoid complicating repairs and preventing issues like air, oil, or water leaks that reduce equipment performance.

column1: How is the gear pair disassembled to maintain precision during reassembly?
column2: ['To improve the precision of the transmission chain, the gear pair with a transmission ratio of 1 is assembled using an error-compensation method: specifically, the tooth space at the point of maximum radial runout on one external gear is engaged with the tooth space at the point of minimum radial runout on the other gear.', 'To prevent errors introduced during reassembly from remaining unresolved, a mark is made at the mating points of the two gears during disassembly, ensuring that the original precision can be restored during reassembly.']
column3: The gear pair is disassembled with careful attention to preserving its precision characteristics. During disassembly, a mark is made at the mating points where the two gears engage. This marking is crucial because the gear pair uses an error-compensation assembly method where the tooth space at the point of maximum radial runout on one external gear engages with the tooth space at the point of minimum radial runout on the other gear. By marking these specific engagement points during disassembly, technicians ensure that the gears can be reassembled in exactly the same orientation, restoring the original precision and maintaining the error-compensation benefits of the transmission system.

column1: What are the key steps for disassembling shaft components from a gearbox?
column2: ["When disassembling shaft components from the gearbox, it is essential to first determine the direction of the shaft's steps, which will dictate the movement direction during removal.", 'Next, remove the shaft caps at both ends, along with any axial positioning parts on the shaft, such as set screws, locknuts, spring washers, and retaining springs.']
column3: The disassembly of shaft components from a gearbox involves two critical steps. First, you must determine the direction of the shaft's steps, as this dictates the correct movement direction for removal to avoid damage. Second, you need to remove the shaft caps located at both ends of the shaft, as well as all axial positioning parts attached to the shaft. These parts include set screws, locknuts, spring washers, and retaining springs, which secure the shaft in place and must be carefully detached to allow safe removal.

column1: What precautions should be taken when disassembling threaded connections?
column2: ['While these connections are relatively easy to dismantle, improper handlingâ€”such as insufficient attention, incorrect tool selection, or improper dismantling techniquesâ€”often leads to damage.', 'Therefore, when removing threaded fasteners, itâ€™s crucial to use the right wrench or screwdriver; always avoid using adjustable wrenches whenever possible.', 'For particularly tough-to-remove threaded joints, first determine the direction of the thread rotation, and never force the connection by twisting randomly or applying excessive leverage with an overly long extension bar.']
column3: When disassembling threaded connections, several precautions are necessary to prevent damage. Always use the correct wrench or screwdriver for the fastener, and avoid adjustable wrenches as they can slip and cause harm. For joints that are difficult to remove, first identify the direction of thread rotation to avoid forcing it incorrectly; never apply random twisting or use an overly long extension bar for excessive leverage, as this can strip or break the fastener. Additionally, when dealing with double-ended studs, it is essential to use a specialized wrench designed specifically for that purpose to ensure safe and effective removal without damaging the components.

column1: How are non-detachable fasteners like welded components disassembled during maintenance?
column2: ['For dismantling welded components, methods such as sawing, plasma cutting, or first drilling small pilot holes with a drill bit before sawing can be used. Alternatively, oxy-acetylene flame cutting is also effective.']
column3: Welded components, which are non-detachable fasteners, can be disassembled using several methods: sawing, plasma cutting, drilling small pilot holes with a drill bit before sawing, or oxy-acetylene flame cutting. These techniques are employed to break the permanent connection without introducing external knowledge, as welding is typically not disassembled during standard maintenance but requires these specific procedures when necessary.

column1: What methods are used to remove riveted components, and what precautions should be taken?
column2: ['As for riveted components, the rivet heads can be removed by chiseling, sawing, or gas cutting, or the rivets themselves can be drilled out using a drill. When performing these operations, care should be taken to avoid damaging the base parts.']
column3: Riveted components, another type of non-detachable fastener, can be removed by methods such as chiseling, sawing, gas cutting to remove the rivet heads, or drilling out the rivets with a drill. It is crucial to exercise caution during these operations to prevent damage to the base parts, ensuring that the disassembly process does not compromise the integrity of the surrounding components.

column1: What factors should be considered when selecting a repair technique for mechanical parts?
column2: ['When repairing damage or defects in mechanical parts, several methods and techniques may be available, but determining the best approach depends on considering the following factors.', '(1) Consider the compatibility of the selected repair technique with the part material.', '(2) Consider the patching layer thicknesses that each repair technique can provide.']
column3: Two primary factors must be considered when selecting a repair technique for mechanical parts. First, the compatibility between the repair technique and the part material must be evaluated to ensure the method is suitable for the specific material. Second, the patching layer thickness that each technique can provide should be assessed, as different parts experience varying degrees of wear and require different thicknesses to compensate for that wear effectively.

column1: Which repair techniques are suitable for low-carbon steel parts?
column2: ['For instance, manual arc welding is ideal for low-carbon steel, medium-carbon steel, and alloy structural steels.', 'Arc surfacing under a flux layer is suitable for low-carbon and medium-carbon steels.']
column3: Low-carbon steel parts can be effectively repaired using manual arc welding, which is ideal for this material along with medium-carbon steel and alloy structural steels. Additionally, arc surfacing under a flux layer is also suitable for low-carbon and medium-carbon steels, providing another viable option for repairing components made from low-carbon steel.

column1: What are the critical indicators for evaluating mechanical part repair quality?
column2: ['The mechanical properties of the repair layerâ€”such as its strength and hardnessâ€”as well as the bond strength between the repair layer and the component, and the changes in surface strength of the part after repairâ€”are critical indicators for evaluating repair quality and serve as the basis for selecting the appropriate restoration technique.']
column3: The critical indicators for evaluating mechanical part repair quality include the mechanical properties of the repair layer itself (specifically its strength and hardness), the bond strength between the repair layer and the original component, and the changes in surface strength of the part after the repair process. These factors collectively determine the effectiveness and durability of the repair and are fundamental in selecting the most suitable restoration technique for any given scenario.

column1: How should operating conditions influence the selection of repair techniques for mechanical parts?
column2: ['Consider the operating conditions and requirements of the mechanical parts. When selecting a repair technique, the working condition of the part should be taken into account. For example, when mechanical parts operate under rolling conditions, the contact surfaces between the two components experience high contact stresses, making repair techniques like chrome plating, spray welding, and overlay welding particularly suitable. In contrast, when mechanical parts function under sliding conditionsâ€”where contact stresses are lowerâ€”the range of applicable repair technologies becomes much broader.', 'When selecting a repair technique, itâ€™s important to consider whether the mechanical part can still meet operational requirements after restoration. For instance, if the chosen repair method involves high temperatures during applicationâ€”such as gas welding or electric weldingâ€”it may cause annealing of the mechanical component, compromising the original surfaceâ€™s heat-treated properties and increasing thermal deformation and residual stresses. Techniques like patch welding or buildup welding, which involve high-temperature processes, are therefore best suited only for non-quenched parts, components that undergo post-weld machining or reshaping, or parts requiring subsequent heat treatment after welding.']
column3: Operating conditions significantly influence repair technique selection. For parts under rolling conditions with high contact stresses, methods like chrome plating, spray welding, and overlay welding are ideal due to their ability to withstand such demands. Conversely, sliding conditions with lower contact stresses allow for a broader range of repair technologies. Additionally, high-temperature processes (e.g., gas welding, electric welding) risk annealing heat-treated parts, increasing deformation and stresses; thus, they are suitable only for non-quenched parts, those needing post-weld machining, or subsequent heat treatment. The key is ensuring the repaired part meets operational requirements without compromising its integrity.

column1: What is gas welding and how does it work?
column2: ['Gas welding A welding method that uses the flame generated by the combustion of a flammable gas mixed with an oxidizing gas as a heat source, melting both the workpiece and the filler material to achieve atomic-level bonding.', 'The primary oxidizing gas is oxygen, while common flammable gases include acetylene, liquefied petroleum gas, and others.']
column3: Gas welding is a welding method that utilizes the flame produced by the combustion of a mixture of flammable gas and oxidizing gas as the heat source. This flame melts both the workpiece and the filler material, enabling atomic-level bonding between them. The primary oxidizing gas used is oxygen, and common flammable gases include acetylene and liquefied petroleum gas, among others.

column1: What are the main advantages and disadvantages of gas welding?
column2: ['Advantages of gas welding: simple equipment, flexible use; excellent adaptability for welding cast iron and certain non-ferrous metals; and a valuable option when welding is needed in areas with insufficient power supply.', 'Drawbacks of gas welding: lower production efficiency; significant workpiece deformation and a larger heat-affected zone after welding; and greater difficulty in achieving automation.']
column3: Gas welding offers several advantages, including simple equipment setup, flexible usage, excellent adaptability for welding cast iron and certain non-ferrous metals, and it serves as a valuable option in areas with insufficient power supply. However, it has drawbacks such as lower production efficiency, significant workpiece deformation and a larger heat-affected zone post-welding, and greater difficulty in achieving automation compared to other welding methods.

column1: What are the advantages and disadvantages of shielded metal arc welding?
column2: ['It remains the most widely used welding method today.', 'The advantages of this method include: simple equipment thatâ€™s easy to maintain, flexible operation, and the ability to weld seams in any spatial positionâ€”essentially anywhere the electrode can reachâ€”making it highly versatile across a wide range of applications.', 'The drawbacks are: high requirements for welders, poor working conditions, and low production efficiency.']
column3: Shielded metal arc welding (SMAW) is the most widely used welding method today. Its key advantages include simple and easily maintainable equipment, flexible operation, and the ability to weld in any spatial position where the electrode can reach, making it highly versatile for various applications. However, it has significant drawbacks: it demands high skill levels from welders, involves poor working conditions, and offers low production efficiency.

column1: What safety precautions should be followed when using shielded metal arc welding equipment?
column2: ['Welding electrode arc welding equipment should be used with the following precautions.', '(1) Check that the wiring is correct and ensure the equipment casing is properly grounded. If a welder experiences electric shock, first disconnect the power supply before administering first aid.', '(2) When operating the power switch, always wear dry gloves and avoid standing directly in front of it to prevent facial burns caused by arc sparks.']
column3: When using shielded metal arc welding equipment, several safety precautions must be followed. First, always check that the wiring is correct and ensure the equipment casing is properly grounded; in case of electric shock, disconnect the power supply before providing first aid. Second, when operating the power switch, wear dry gloves and avoid standing directly in front to prevent facial burns from arc sparks. Third, do not place welding cables near the welding machine or on hot metal welds, and protect them from collisions and abrasion to maintain safety and equipment integrity.

column1: What factors should be considered when selecting welding electrodes?
column2: ['When selecting welding electrodes, itâ€™s essential to consider the material properties of the workpiece, the working conditions, and the specific structural features.']
column3: The selection of welding electrodes must be based on three key factors: the material properties of the workpiece being welded, the specific working conditions under which the welding will occur, and the structural features of the component. This ensures that the electrode is appropriate for the application and will produce a quality weld.

column1: What is surfacing welding and what are its characteristics?
column2: ["Surfacing Welding Using welding techniques, a layer or several layers of material with desired properties are deposited onto the part. This process can restore the part's dimensions and even enhance its performance by improving the surface characteristics of the component.", 'Compared to the entire machine part, the weld overlay is typically very thin, with the primary requirement being high surface wear resistance.', 'Notably, the weld overlay material often differs from the base material, which can lead to challenges in weldability due to these material property differences.']
column3: Surfacing welding is a process where one or multiple layers of material with specific desired properties are deposited onto a part using welding techniques. This method serves to restore the part's original dimensions and can enhance its performance by improving surface characteristics. The weld overlay is typically very thin compared to the entire machine part, with the main requirement being high surface wear resistance. A notable challenge is that the surfacing material often differs from the base material, which can create weldability issues due to material property differences. Handheld arc surfacing equipment offers simplicity, flexibility, and cost-effectiveness, making it particularly suitable for irregularly shaped parts and hard-to-reach components. However, this method has limitations including low productivity and difficulty in achieving thin, uniform surfacing layers.

column1: What is brazing and how does it work?
column2: ["Use a metal material with a melting point lower than that of the base material as the brazing filler metal, and heat the workpiecesâ€”where the filler metal has been placedâ€”to a temperature above the filler metal's melting point but below the base material's melting point.", 'The method of joining components by using a liquid brazing filler metal that wets the base material at its melting point, fills the joint gap, and then diffuses into the base material to form a strong bond is called brazing.']
column3: Brazing is a method of joining components by using a brazing filler metal that has a lower melting point than the base material. The process involves placing the filler metal between the workpieces and heating them to a temperature above the filler metal's melting point but below that of the base material. This causes the filler metal to melt, wet the base material, fill the joint gap through capillary action, and then diffuse into the base material to form a strong bond.

column1: What are the differences between hard brazing and soft brazing?
column2: ['Brazing is divided into hard brazing and soft brazing. Brazing performed using filler metals with melting points above 450Â°C is commonly referred to as hard brazing, examples include copper brazing and silver brazing; while brazing conducted with filler metals having melting points below 450Â°C is typically called soft brazing, such as tin soldering and lead soldering.']
column3: Hard brazing and soft brazing are distinguished by the melting point of the filler metal used. Hard brazing employs filler metals with melting points above 450Â°C, such as copper or silver brazing alloys, and is used for higher-temperature applications. Soft brazing uses filler metals with melting points below 450Â°C, like tin-lead or lead-based solders, and is suitable for lower-temperature joining processes.

column1: What are the advantages of the spray welding repair process?
column2: ['The process is flexible, requires few operational steps, allows for quick repairs, and reduces machining time.', 'Highly adaptable, generally unrestricted by workpiece size or site conditions.', 'Coating thickness can be controlled.']
column3: The spray welding repair process offers several key advantages: It is highly flexible and adaptable, with few operational steps, making it efficient and straightforward to perform. This adaptability means it is generally not restricted by workpiece size or site conditions, allowing for versatile application. The process enables quick repairs with short cycles, high productivity, and low costs, reducing overall machining time. Coating thickness can be precisely controlled, and the base material is heated to a lower temperature, which minimizes workpiece deformation and results in only slight changes to microstructure and mechanical properties. Additionally, it can use various substrate materials to create a wide range of protective and functional coatings on nearly all solid material surfaces, enhancing properties like oxidation resistance, electrical conductivity, insulation, and thermal insulation.

column1: What are the main methods and benefits of surface mechanical strengthening?
column2: ['Surface mechanical strengthening involves inducing compressive deformation in the metal surface of a part through methods such as shot peening, roll forming, and internal extrusion, creating a hardened layer measuring 0.3 to 1.5 mm in thickness on the surface.', "Shot peening involves blasting high-velocity projectiles onto a component's surface, inducing intense plastic deformation in the metal material and creating a cold-worked layer with elevated residual stressesâ€”known as the shot-peened layer.", "Shot peening enhances a material's resistance to fatigue fracture, preventing fatigue failure, plastic deformation, and brittle fracture while extending its fatigue life."]
column3: Surface mechanical strengthening primarily utilizes methods such as shot peening, roll forming, and internal extrusion to induce compressive deformation in the metal surface of a part. This process creates a hardened layer with a thickness ranging from 0.3 to 1.5 mm. Shot peening works by blasting high-velocity projectiles onto the surface, causing intense plastic deformation and forming a cold-worked layer with elevated residual stresses, known as the shot-peened layer. This significantly enhances the material's resistance to fatigue fracture, helping to prevent fatigue failure, plastic deformation, and brittle fracture, thereby extending the component's fatigue life. Rolling enhancement involves applying a specific rolling force using a diamond or other rolling head, which hardens the surface through strain-induced strengthening and improves mechanical properties. These techniques are widely applicable across industries like machinery, aerospace, marine, petroleum, mining, railways, transportation, heavy machinery, and military equipment, offering improved durability and performance.

column1: What is Electrical Discharge Surface Enhancement?
column2: ['By using the discharge effect of an electric spark, a conductive material is applied and melted into the surface of another conductive material, thereby altering the surface properties of the latter.']
column3: Electrical Discharge Surface Enhancement is a process that utilizes the discharge effect of an electric spark to apply and melt a conductive material onto the surface of another conductive material. This technique alters the surface properties of the base material by integrating the applied conductive material through spark-induced melting and fusion.

column1: What are the benefits of strengthening equipment management?
column2: ['Strengthening equipment management and ensuring proper maintenance will keep machinery consistently in excellent condition, thereby extending its lifespan.', "This not only plays a critical role in boosting production volume and variety, enhancing labor productivity, reducing consumption, lowering costs, and safeguarding worker safetyâ€”but also significantly contributes to upgrading the company's overall production technology, accelerating industrial growth, and protecting productive capacity."]
column3: Strengthening equipment management provides multiple significant benefits. It ensures machinery remains in excellent condition through proper maintenance, which extends equipment lifespan. This approach boosts production volume and variety while enhancing labor productivity. It also reduces consumption and lowers operational costs while safeguarding worker safety. Additionally, it contributes to upgrading the company's overall production technology, accelerates industrial growth, and protects productive capacity, making it essential for achieving optimal economic results with minimal resources.

column1: What is the purpose of equipment maintenance information management?
column2: ['The task of equipment maintenance information management is to establish a comprehensive information system that collects, stores, and organizes all types of equipment-related data, while also enabling data processing, output, and feedbackâ€”ultimately supporting informed economic and technical decision-making for equipment management.']
column3: The purpose of equipment maintenance information management is to establish a comprehensive information system that collects, stores, and organizes all types of equipment-related data. This system enables data processing, output, and feedback mechanisms, which ultimately support informed economic and technical decision-making for equipment management. Without such a systematic and reliable information system, effective management becomes difficult to implement, making this function critical for corporate equipment maintenance activities where various technical and economic decisions must be made based on accurate information.

column1: What are the key functions of a computer maintenance information system in equipment repair and management?
column2: ['The computer maintenance information system offers the following key functions in equipment repair and management: 1) Process Control Function The process control function can be used to monitor equipment operating conditions and detect key performance parameters such as vibration, noise, ultrasound, temperature rise, cooling status, lubrication condition, and environmental factors, providing critical information to guide maintenance activities.', '2) Engineering Design and Calculation Functionality The engineering design and calculation function enables mechanical analysis and computations for various equipment and maintenance tooling, as well as supports computer-aided design and drafting, along with diverse optimization processes.', '3) Information Processing Function The information processing function handles various types of data in maintenance management, covering the following 5 aspects: (1) Equipment Ledger Management. Store the original data and documentation for all company equipment in a computer system, allowing you to generate workshop equipment ledgers and equipment lists by modelâ€”in various formatsâ€”as needed. (2) Equipment classification, sorting, querying, and retrieval. Categorize and sort equipment supply information available in the market, storing it in the system to provide insights when companies update or add new equipment. (3) Equipment Maintenance Planning Management. When determining equipment maintenance plans, you can refer to equipment records, maintenance information, and diagnostic data stored in the computer system, and, based on actual conditions, use the computer to develop annual, quarterly, and monthly equipment maintenance schedules. (4) Maintenance Spare Parts Management. By entering the enterprise equipment maintenance spare partsâ€?demand information, inventory details, and inbound/outbound records into the computer system, users can instantly access real-time inventory status and generate statistical reports. Additionally, an alert notification can be automatically triggered when the current stock level drops below the predefined warning threshold. (5) Other functions. The computer system can also provide service functionalities to the maintenance system, including personnel management, financial management, and technical and process management.']
column3: The computer maintenance information system provides three core functions in equipment repair and management. First, the Process Control Function monitors equipment operating conditions by detecting key performance parameters including vibration, noise, ultrasound, temperature rise, cooling status, lubrication condition, and environmental factors, delivering critical information to guide maintenance decisions. Second, the Engineering Design and Calculation Functionality supports mechanical analysis and computations for equipment and maintenance tooling, facilitates computer-aided design and drafting, and enables various optimization processes. Third, the Information Processing Function manages maintenance data across five specific areas: Equipment Ledger Management stores all company equipment data and documentation, enabling generation of workshop ledgers and model-specific lists; Equipment Classification, Sorting, Querying, and Retrieval organizes market equipment supply information to assist in equipment updates or additions; Equipment Maintenance Planning Management uses stored records, maintenance information, and diagnostic data to help develop annual, quarterly, and monthly maintenance schedules; Maintenance Spare Parts Management tracks demand, inventory, and inbound/outbound records for real-time status access, statistical reporting, and automatic low-stock alerts; and Other Functions provide additional services like personnel management, financial management, and technical/process management.

column1: What is the equipment maintenance complexity factor and how is it used?
column2: ['The equipment maintenance complexity factor, also known as the maintenance complexity unit or simply the maintenance unit, is a hypothetical measure used to assess the intricacy of equipment repair tasks, determine the associated workload, and establish standard benchmarks for various metrics.', "This assumed unit represents the maintenance effort required for a specific type of machinery, with its value determined by factors such as the equipment's structural design, dimensions, size, and precision levels. In general, the more complex the equipment's structure, the larger its physical dimensions, and the higher the machining accuracy demanded, the greater its maintenance complexity factor will be.", 'For instance, in metal-cutting machine tools, the C620 latheâ€”typically featuring a maximum workpiece diameter of 400 mm and a maximum workpiece length of 1,000 mmâ€”is often used as the benchmark machine. Its maintenance complexity factor is standardized at 10. As for electrical equipment, the focus shifts toâ€?A protected cage-type synchronous motor with a rated power of 0.6 kW is standard equipment, and its maintenance complexity factor is specified as 1.']
column3: The equipment maintenance complexity factor, also referred to as the maintenance complexity unit or maintenance unit, is a hypothetical standardized measure designed to evaluate the complexity of equipment repair tasks, quantify associated workloads, and set benchmarks for maintenance metrics. Its value is determined by specific equipment characteristics including structural design, dimensions, physical size, and precision requirementsâ€”generally, more complex structures, larger dimensions, and higher precision demands result in a higher complexity factor. For example, in metal-cutting machine tools, the C620 lathe (with a maximum workpiece diameter of 400 mm and length of 1,000 mm) serves as the benchmark with a standardized factor of 10, while for electrical equipment, a protected cage-type synchronous motor rated at 0.6 kW is the standard with a factor of 1. Other machinery is assessed by comparing their structural, size, and precision attributes to these standard units. Once the labor quota for one maintenance unit (denoted as "R") is defined, it enables calculation of maintenance workloads for any machine type. Furthermore, the maintenance unit serves as a basis for deriving maintenance downtime quotas and cost estimates. Enterprises establish these factors for different equipment and machine tools, with separate values for mechanical and electrical systems, and formalize them into company standards to guide maintenance activities.

column1: What is the maintenance labor quota and how is it calculated?
column2: ['The maintenance labor quota refers to the amount of labor time required by a company to complete various repair tasks for machinery and equipment, typically expressed as the number of work hours needed for a single repair complexity factor.', 'For example, the labor quota for a major overhaul of a machine tool with one repair complexity factor includes 40 hours for fitters, 20 hours for machining operations, and 4 hours for other trades, totaling 64 hours.']
column3: The maintenance labor quota is defined as the amount of labor time required to complete repair tasks for machinery and equipment, measured in work hours per single repair complexity factor. It quantifies the total labor investment needed for repairs. For instance, a major overhaul of a machine tool with one repair complexity factor requires 40 hours of fitter work, 20 hours for machining operations, and 4 hours for other trades, summing to a total of 64 hours. This standardized approach helps companies plan and allocate labor resources efficiently for maintenance activities.

column1: What is standard maintenance downtime and why is it important to minimize it?
column2: ['The standard maintenance downtime refers to the time taken from when equipment is handed over for repair until the repair is completed and accepted. This duration is determined based on the maintenance complexity factor.', "Generally speaking, the higher the maintenance complexity factor, the more intricate the equipment's structureâ€”and most of these devices are critical, key components in production that significantly impact operational efficiency. Therefore, it is essential to minimize maintenance downtime as much as possible to ensure smooth production processes."]
column3: Standard maintenance downtime is the period from when equipment is handed over for repair until it is completed and accepted, with its duration based on the maintenance complexity factor. Equipment with higher complexity factors tends to have more intricate structures and are often critical, key components in production, directly affecting operational efficiency. Minimizing this downtime is crucial to avoid disruptions and ensure smooth production processes, as prolonged repairs can lead to significant operational delays and reduced productivity.

column1: What are the time-phased categories of equipment maintenance plans?
column2: ['The time-phased plans include: â‘?The annual maintenance plan, which encompasses all major, medium, and minor repair schedules for the enterprise throughout the year, as well as regular equipment maintenance and upgrade/installation plans. This plan should be completed by the end of the previous year. â‘?The quarterly maintenance plan, derived from the annual plan, further breaks down the yearly objectives into more detailed tasks. It also allows for timely adjustments and additions to project timelines and sequences based on actual conditions, typically finalized during the last month of the preceding quarter. â‘?The monthly maintenance plan, which is even more specific and meticulous than the quarterly plan, serves as the operational blueprint for executing maintenance activities.']
column3: The time-phased equipment maintenance plans consist of three categories: the annual maintenance plan, the quarterly maintenance plan, and the monthly maintenance plan. The annual maintenance plan includes all major, medium, and minor repair schedules for the entire year, along with regular equipment maintenance and upgrade/installation plans, and it must be completed by the end of the previous year. The quarterly maintenance plan is derived from the annual plan, breaking down yearly objectives into more detailed tasks and allowing for adjustments to project timelines and sequences based on actual conditions; it is typically finalized in the last month of the preceding quarter. The monthly maintenance plan is the most specific and meticulous, serving as the operational blueprint for maintenance execution, incorporating critical tasks like routine upkeep, periodic inspections, and scheduled diagnostics.

column1: What is the purpose of the maintenance budget?
column2: ['The budget is primarily intended for corporate finance departments to prepare funds for major repairs and control major repair expenses. Some companies also prepare budgets for itemized repairs and minor maintenance tasks.']
column3: The maintenance budget is primarily used by corporate finance departments to prepare and allocate funds specifically for major repairs, as well as to control and manage major repair expenses. Additionally, some companies extend the budget to cover itemized repairs and minor maintenance tasks, ensuring comprehensive financial planning for all types of maintenance activities.

column1: What is the basis for preparing a maintenance plan?
column2: ['Basis for preparing the maintenance plan. â‘?The technical condition of equipment refers to its actual state in terms of technical performance, load capacity, transmission mechanisms, and operational safety.', 'Key indicators reflecting the quality of a companyâ€™s equipmentâ€”including equipment integrity rate, failure downtime rate, and the extent to which equipment impacts balanced productionâ€”provide a clear picture of the overall technical condition.', 'Information on equipmentâ€™s technical status is primarily gathered through comprehensive surveys and assessments of equipment conditions, as well as from original documentation.']
column3: The basis for preparing a maintenance plan consists of two main components: the technical condition of equipment and production process requirements. The technical condition refers to the equipment's actual state regarding technical performance, load capacity, transmission mechanisms, and operational safety, which is assessed through key indicators such as equipment integrity rate, failure downtime rate, and impact on balanced production. This information is gathered through comprehensive equipment surveys typically conducted in the third quarter of each year, where companies identify existing issues, propose corrective measures, and complete the Equipment Technical Condition Survey Form. Additionally, original documentation including daily inspections, routine checks, condition-monitoring logs, repair histories, and analytical data provides crucial information. Equipment showing deteriorating technical conditions is included in the annual maintenance plan. The second basis comes from production process requirements - if equipment fails to meet process and quality standards for products, the process department submits requests for planned maintenance.

column1: What factors should be considered when preparing an equipment maintenance plan?
column2: ['Equipment critical to production needs, impacting product quality, and essential to key processes should be prioritized.', 'Single critical equipment on the production line should, whenever possible, be scheduled for maintenance during holidays to minimize downtime.', 'Equipment for continuous or periodic production (thermal and power equipment) must be properly scheduled according to their specific characteristics, ensuring that equipment maintenance is closely integrated with production tasks.']
column3: When preparing an equipment maintenance plan, several critical factors must be considered. First, prioritize equipment that is essential to production needs, impacts product quality, and is critical to key processes. For single critical equipment on production lines, schedule maintenance during holidays whenever possible to minimize operational downtime. Equipment used in continuous or periodic production, such as thermal and power equipment, must be scheduled according to their specific characteristics to ensure maintenance is integrated with production tasks. Special requirements for precision equipment maintenance should be addressed. Additionally, balance the maintenance workload to distribute repair activities evenly throughout the year, prioritizing tasks based on urgency and importance. Consider the workload and timeline for pre-repair production technology preparation. Arrange similar equipment maintenance continuously when feasible. Finally, comprehensively assess the availability of necessary technology, materials, labor, and funding sources for the maintenance activities.

column1: What are the steps involved in compiling an annual maintenance plan?

This assessment includes analyzing the ease or difficulty of performing the necessary repairs. While the content mentions that there are five steps total, only the first step is detailed here, which focuses on evaluating equipment condition and repair complexity to inform the planning process.

column1: What are the four steps in preparing the annual equipment maintenance plan?

When drafting, fully consider how the annual production plan impacts equipment requirements, ensuring that maintenance schedules are aligned with production plans.', 'â‘?Balanced Approval. After the draft plan is completed, it is distributed to the production, planning, engineering, technical, finance, and user departments for discussion.']
column3: The annual equipment maintenance plan preparation consists of four sequential steps. First, information gathering involves thorough data collection and analysis of technical condition data (original documentation, equipment inspection forms, product process requirements, quality-related information) and production data (annual production schedule, maintenance quotas, technical specifications, spare parts inventory). Second, draft preparation requires aligning maintenance schedules with production plans to prevent under-maintenance or over-maintenance, followed by technical and economic analysis involving multiple departments. Third, balanced approval involves distributing the draft to production, planning, engineering, technical, finance, and user departments for modifications and comprehensive evaluation before formal submission. Fourth, execution issuance occurs before December when the production planning department formally issues the finalized plan as the operational basis for the following year.

Finally, preliminary measures and recommendations should be proposed to address these crucial challenges effectively.']
